Reference

All functions

agg() scale()

Aggregate/Scale a detailed level of a hierarchical variable to an aggregate level

agg_subtree() scale_subtree()

Aggregate or scale one subtree's children values to the parent level

assert_agg_scale_args()

Check inputs to agg and scale functions

assert_is_unique_dt() identify_non_unique_dt()

Are the rows of the input data.table unique?

collapse_tree()

Collapse the data.tree so that intermediate nodes without data are removed

create_base_tree()

Create a data.tree object using a mapping of levels of a categorical or interval variable

create_interval_node()

Create a node for an interval tree

create_agg_interval_tree() create_scale_interval_tree()

Create a data.tree object to be used for aggregating or scaling interval data

create_agg_subtrees() create_scale_subtrees()

Create a list of subtrees that can be used during aggregation or scaling

create_agg_tree() create_scale_tree() vis_tree()

Create a data.tree object to be used for aggregating or scaling hierarchical categorical or interval data

demUtils

demUtils: A package with utility functions for common demographics data and estimation problems

fill_missing_intervals()

create new interval nodes for any missing interval nodes

gen_end() gen_length() gen_name()

Generate columns to help describe numeric variable intervals

identify_agg_dt_issues() identify_scale_dt_issues()

Identify issues in the input dataset for aggregation and scaling functions

identify_unique_groupings()

Determine unique sets of the agg/scale variable present in the input data.table

iran_mapping

Iran Provinces Mapping from 1950 to Today

iran_pop

Iran Census Population Counts

name_to_start_end()

Parse interval notation name to interval endpoints

place_new_interval_node()

Place a new interval node in an interval tree

identify_missing_intervals() identify_overlapping_intervals()

Identify missing or overlapping intervals

identify_missing_agg() identify_missing_scale() identify_present_agg()

Identify names of problematic nodes in categorical trees

subset_unique_grouping()

Subset to data for one unique set of the agg/scale variable
